title: Trajectory
text:
A trajectory or flight path is the path that an <a href="physical%20body">object</a> with <a href="mass">mass</a> in <a href="Motion%20%28physics%29">motion</a> follows through <a href="space">space</a> as a function of time. In <a href="classical%20mechanics">classical mechanics</a>, a trajectory is defined by <a href="Hamiltonian%20mechanics">Hamiltonian mechanics</a> via <a href="canonical%20coordinates">canonical coordinates</a>; hence, a complete trajectory is defined by position and momentum, simultaneously.
The mass might be a <a href="projectile">projectile</a> or a <a href="satellite">satellite</a>. For example, it can be an <a href="orbit">orbit</a> — the path of a <a href="planet">planet</a>, <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a>, or <a href="comet">comet</a> as it travels around a <a href="primary%20%28astronomy%29">central mass</a>.
In <a href="control%20theory">control theory</a>, a trajectory is a time-ordered set of <a href="state%20%28controls%29">state</a>s of a <a href="dynamical%20system">dynamical system</a> (see e.g. <a href="Poincar%C3%A9%20map">Poincaré map</a>). In <a href="discrete%20mathematics">discrete mathematics</a>, a trajectory is a sequence formula_1 of values calculated by the iterated application of a mapping formula_2 to an element formula_3 of its source.
Physics of trajectories.
A familiar example of a trajectory is the path of a projectile, such as a thrown ball or rock. In a significantly simplified model, the object moves only under the influence of a uniform gravitational <a href="Force%20field%20%28physics%29">force field</a>. This can be a good approximation for a rock that is thrown for short distances, for example at the surface of the <a href="moon">moon</a>. In this simple approximation, the trajectory takes the shape of a <a href="parabola">parabola</a>. Generally when determining trajectories, it may be necessary to account for nonuniform gravitational forces and air resistance (<a href="drag%20%28physics%29">drag</a> and <a href="aerodynamics">aerodynamics</a>). This is the focus of the discipline of <a href="ballistics">ballistics</a>.
One of the remarkable achievements of <a href="Newtonian%20mechanics">Newtonian mechanics</a> was the derivation of the <a href="laws%20of%20Kepler">laws of Kepler</a>. In the gravitational field of a point mass or a spherically-symmetrical extended mass (such as the <a href="Sun">Sun</a>), the trajectory of a moving object is a <a href="conic%20section">conic section</a>, usually an <a href="ellipse">ellipse</a> or a <a href="hyperbola">hyperbola</a>. This agrees with the observed orbits of <a href="planets">planets</a>, <a href="comets">comets</a>, and artificial spacecraft to a reasonably good approximation, although if a comet passes close to the Sun, then it is also influenced by other <a href="force">force</a>s such as the <a href="solar%20wind">solar wind</a> and <a href="radiation%20pressure">radiation pressure</a>, which modify the orbit and cause the comet to eject material into space.
Newton's theory later developed into the branch of <a href="theoretical%20physics">theoretical physics</a> known as <a href="classical%20mechanics">classical mechanics</a>. It employs the mathematics of <a href="differential%20calculus">differential calculus</a> (which was also initiated by Newton in his youth). Over the centuries, countless scientists have contributed to the development of these two disciplines. Classical mechanics became a most prominent demonstration of the power of rational thought, i.e. <a href="reason">reason</a>, in science as well as technology. It helps to understand and predict an enormous range of <a href="phenomena">phenomena</a>; trajectories are but one example.
Consider a particle of <a href="mass">mass</a> formula_4, moving in a <a href="Gravitational%20potential">potential field</a> formula_5. Physically speaking, mass represents <a href="inertia">inertia</a>, and the field formula_5 represents external forces of a particular kind known as "conservative". Given formula_5 at every relevant position, there is a way to infer the associated force that would act at that position, say from gravity. Not all forces can be expressed in this way, however.
The motion of the particle is described by the second-order <a href="differential%20equation">differential equation</a>
On the right-hand side, the force is given in terms of formula_9, the <a href="gradient">gradient</a> of the potential, taken at positions along the trajectory. This is the mathematical form of Newton's <a href="Newton%27s%20second%20law">second law of motion</a>: force equals mass times acceleration, for such situations.
Examples.
Uniform gravity, neither drag nor wind.
The ideal case of motion of a projectile in a uniform gravitational field in the absence of other forces (such as air drag) was first investigated by <a href="Galileo%20Galilei">Galileo Galilei</a>. To neglect the action of the atmosphere in shaping a trajectory would have been considered a futile hypothesis by practical-minded investigators all through the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> in <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. Nevertheless, by anticipating the existence of the <a href="vacuum">vacuum</a>, later to be demonstrated on <a href="Earth">Earth</a> by his collaborator <a href="Evangelista%20Torricelli">Evangelista Torricelli</a>, Galileo was able to initiate the future science of <a href="mechanics">mechanics</a>. In a near vacuum, as it turns out for instance on the <a href="Moon">Moon</a>, his simplified parabolic trajectory proves essentially correct.

Range and height.
The range, "R", is the greatest distance the object travels along the <a href="x-axis">x-axis</a> in the I sector. The initial velocity, "vi", is the speed at which said object is launched from the point of origin. The initial angle, "θi", is the angle at which said object is released. The "g" is the respective gravitational pull on the object within a null-medium.
The height, "h", is the greatest parabolic height said object reaches within its trajectory

Orbiting objects.
If instead of a uniform downwards gravitational force we consider two bodies <a href="orbit">orbit</a>ing with the mutual gravitation between them, we obtain <a href="Kepler%27s%20laws%20of%20planetary%20motion">Kepler's laws of planetary motion</a>. The derivation of these was one of the major works of <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a> and provided much of the motivation for the development of <a href="differential%20calculus">differential calculus</a>.
Catching balls.
If a projectile, such as a baseball or cricket ball, travels in a parabolic path, with negligible air resistance, and if a player is positioned so as to catch it as it descends, he sees its angle of elevation increasing continuously throughout its flight. The tangent of the angle of elevation is proportional to the time since the ball was sent into the air, usually by being struck with a bat. Even when the ball is really descending, near the end of its flight, its angle of elevation seen by the player continues to increase. The player therefore sees it as if it were ascending vertically at constant speed. Finding the place from which the ball appears to rise steadily helps the player to position himself correctly to make the catch. If he is too close to the batsman who has hit the ball, it will appear to rise at an accelerating rate. If he is too far from the batsman, it will appear to slow rapidly, and then to descend.
